lines.text: What do you want?
What I've always wanted. To watch you die.
Mike, are you sure you wanna go this way? I mean we buried this a long time ago.
You still sleep with the light on?

[after handing Detective Davenport surveillance photos and proof that Adam Styler's a crooked cop]
So, you got enough for conviction?
That ain't up to me. That's up to a jury.

[hands Davenport a gun in a plastic bag]
Show the jury this.
What do you got there, Ness?
About 3 weeks ago, the body of a drug dealer named Indian Red Lopez was found in an alley in Jackson Heights. Three bullets in his head, nothing in his pockets.
I'm with you so far.
This is the gun that killed him, and these are the shells.
What's behind door number 3?
The prints on the gun belong to Adam Styler.
Hey, do me a favor, would you?
What's that?
If I ever make it onto your shit list, give me a call. Give me a chance to apologize.
Don't you guys have to go kill somebody?
No, We've always got time for a song!
You read the Count of Monte Cristo lately?
I dunno, 10 years ago
I read a little bit every night. I read words like revenge, sweet, lasting revenge.
It was the Sistine Chapel he painted.
Sixteenth Chapel?
Sistine Chapel.
Who painted the other fifteen?

[Sadly]
I want to be able to sleep one night and not worry about who's coming in my room or what's gonna happen to me. If I can get that, then I'll be happy.

The street is the only thing that matters. Court is for uptown people with suits, money, lawyers with three names. If you got cash you can buy court justice. But on the street, justice has no price. She's blind where the judge sits but she's not blind out here. Out here the bitch got eyes.

[narrating about Father Bobby]
I told him about the torture, the beating and the rapes. I told him about four frightened boys who prayed to Father Bobby's God for help that never came. I told him everything.
This is amazing!
Hello! It's been a long time!
Who the fuck are you guys?
[John and Tommy each pull up a chair and sit down at Nokes' table]
Hey, who the fuck asked you to sit down?
I thought you'd be happy to see us... I guess I was wrong.
You know, after all that training, after all that time you put in, just guarding someone else's money... that seems like a waste!
I'm asking you one more time who the fuck you are!
Why don't you take your time it will come to you!
[Nokes stares at them, thinking]
I can see how you might forget. We were just something for you and your friends to play with.
It's not that easy for us to forget... you gave us so much more to remember.

A number of the inmates, as tough as they acted during the day, would often cry themself to sleep at night. There were other cries, too. Diffrent from those full with fear and lonelyness. They were low and muffled, the sounds of pain and anguish.Those cries can change the course of a life. They are cries that once heard, can never be erased from the memory. On this one night those cries belonged to my friend John, when guard Ferguson paid him a visit.
right here, Hell's Kitchen. It is the lost and found of shit. They lose it and we find it. Forget about it, man.
We can eat hot dogs, or we can eat air. Choose...
Air is probably safer, Mike...
I just wish I could shut my eyes, and not see the places I've been.
I'm telling you as a witness... and as a priest. We were at the game.
Yes, as a priest, and a priest wouldn't lie? Am I right?
A priest with ticket stubs wouldn't need to lie. I always keep the stubs. Do you want to see them?
Why is that, Father? Why do you keep the stubs?
Because you never know when someone might want more than your word.
Has anyone ever questioned your word before today?
No. No one ever has. But there's a first time for everything.
And you won't need a doctor when I'm done, you'll need a priest - to pray over your body.
[pause]
See you in church.
What do you want?
A blowjob. Down on your knees.
I didn't know you like pigeons so much.
I like anything that don't talk.
There are no clear pictures of the sexual abuse we endured. I buried it as deep as it can possibly go.
The plan, as it turned out, was as simple and as dumb as anything we'd ever done.
Why is Saturday any different?
cause on Saturday we can hit back, look they don't fuck with you like they do with us, but they fuck with you in another way, you're just an animal to them.
I don't give a fuck
Yeah you do, and beating them on Saturday won't make a difference.
Then why, white boy, why?
To make them feel what we feel, just for a couple of hours.
Hey, uh, Father. How long did it take him? You know, paintin' the ceiling and all?
Took him about nine years.
Nine years?
That's right.

[laugh]
For a ceiling? I had a Puerto Rican guy do my whole apartment in two days... and he had a bum leg.
The temperature topped out at ninety-eight degrees the day our lives were forever altered.
The man I know is not the boy you remember.
None of us are.

[to Shakes' mother]
I buried one fucking wife, I can bury another.

[about Shakes' prank in the church]
Nuns are such easy targets.

[narrating]
Hell's Kitchen was a place of innocence ruled by corruption.
[voice over]
Most priests like to preach from the pulpit. Father Bobby liked to talk during the bump and shove of a pick-up game.
Listen, I got a story I want to tell you.
It ain't the one about the lepers, is it? Cause that one gave me nightmares.

[about sermons, before the boys are sentenced]
This is one of my favorites.
What is?
"Whatever you do to the least of brethren, you do to me".
I stopped off at Attica today on my way up here to see an old friend of mine.
You have any friends who aren't in jail?
Not as many as I'd like.
One down, Shakes, one down.
One what?
One Sean Nokes.
You gotta get me one for our side.
One what?
One witness. A witness who'll put John and Tommy somewhere else on the night of the murder. A witness they can't touch
Don't they got a name for that?
A judge would call it perjury.
I see, and what are we calling it?
A favor.
What about the life that was taken, Shakes? What's that worth?
To me? Nothing.
[first lines]

This is a true story about friendship that runs deeper than blood. This is my story and that of the only three friends in my life that truely mattered. Two of them were killers who never made it past the age of 30. The other's a non-practicing attorney living with the pain of his past - too afraid to let it go, never confronting its horror. I'm the only one who can speak for them, and the children we were.
They killed him?
They took turns beating him... until there was nothing left of that kid to beat.
Revenge. Sweet lasting revenge. Now it's time for all of us to get a taste.
Michael was the most sexually experienced of us, which means he had kissed a girl on more than two occasions.
I couldn't look at him. He might look right through the fear and the shame, right through to the truth.
[last lines]
The future lay sparkling ahead, and we thought we would know each other forever.

[to Inmates after breaking up fight]
You know your time here hasn't taught you shit. You're still the same fucking clowns you were the day you walked in here.
Did you observe these experiences?
Ye, ye, ye, yes.
Did you more then *observe* these experiences?

[about The Count of Monte Cristo]
We can discuss the book on Friday if you think the count can hold their attention.
He's got a shot.
Any particular section I should read from?
That's easy, the part where he escapes from prison.
I could die now, and I wouldn't be sad.

[Watching Shakes undress and sees he's wearing a necklace]
What the fuck is that hangin' around your neck? Take it off.
It's Mary, you know, the mother of God.

[scoffs]
I don't give a fuck whose mother it is. Take it off.
[Nokes is escorting Shakes, Mike, John, and Tommy down a corridor]

It's a tragedy, I tell ya. I don't understand you, boys. I don't think you know what it means to have rules. You gotta have rules and you gotta have discipline. Now I don't know what it was like in your homes and your homelifes, but in my house with my father, there were rules. And if you didn't follow the rules, there was hell to pay. You had rules and you had discipline. Sometimes it wasn't nice, but boy, we learned. We sure did learn.
[the boys enter a storage room where the other three guards are waiting]

Yeah, right around there to the right. There ya go. Come on now. I mean, it's a simple thing really. You got rules and you got discipline. That's the beginning of the story and that's the end of the story. Do we understand each other?

[after breaking up fight]
So you Hell's Kitchen's Boys get any lunch?
I got to smell it.

[laughing]
You got to smell it, that's good
[boys start walking back to line]
, Hey, Hey, Hey, where you going?
You said to get lunch.
Oh, you boys don't need to get back in line to get lunch 'cause there's plenty to eat right where you're standing
[looks at food on floor]
, YOU CAN SMELL IT.

[looks at food in disbelief and shock]
I'm not hungry.
Well I don't give a fuck if you're hungry or not. You eat because I'm telling to eat.

[looks down at food again]
I'm still not hungry!

[gets Hit by Nightstick]
Uh, Ooh!
I'll tell you when you're hungry or not, now eat!

[looks at Shakes, Tommy, and John]
Excuse me, what the fuck are you looking at? GET THE FUCK DOWN ON YOUR GODDAMN KNEES AND FINISH YOUR GODDAMN LUNCH!
I can't do this now. You gotta know that. It's been a long time for me. I mean -ah- you need somebody younger, ya know, somebody like I used to be.
younger is not better. Doesn't have experience, doesn't know his way around the courthouse.
Hey, I'm lucky I can find the courthouse. I had only four cases last year-you know how many I won? None, that's how many, none. In two of them, uh, I, a, I think the jury blamed me personnally.
They must have been innocent. It is tough to get an innocent man off a rap.
I wasn't even planning on going to court with this one. I was just gonna plea it down the best I could and walk away. I wasn't, I wasn't planning on taking this to trial.
Well your plans have been changed.
Well I'm afraid I'll make a mistake and... say the wrong thing and, ya know, uh, uh, make a wrong turn somewhere. You don't want to take that risk.
Life is a risk.
I'm sorry?
Life is risk.
Life is a risk.
Um-huh.
A-huh.I haven't been in here before. What do you need me to do?
Listen. You're going to be given the answers and the questions. All you have to do is read. You can read can't you?
It's, it's, is it in English?
Just don't drift, don't drink, and don't lose.
What if I do lose?
Then you'll go down for the dirt nap.

Never heard that expression before... dirt nap. I'm not cut out for this anymore. I mean a guys gets hit by a bus, ya know, and sues. I like that. Some lady slips in a supermarket, I'm with her, a guy...
The discussion's over.
I'm an alcoholic. This is a murder case. This isn't for me.
It was once. Before you let the drink lead. Be sober by tomorrow and don't look so worried, Snyder. You have nothing to lose, just like the rest of us.
I don't want to be a burden to you, but, I do, you know, aside, or along with my alcohol problem, I have a slight drug problem, I mean nothing big, just...
Go away.

[after John shot Nokes in the groin]
Did that hurt, Nokes?
He should not have to do time. Nobody in this family should have to do time. I've done enough time for *everybody*!
[voice over]

Young protesters spoke about how they'd change our lives and fix the world. But while they shouted their slogans, my friends and I went to the funeral services of the young men of Hell's Kitchen who came back from Vietnam in body bags.
Father Bobby would have made a good hitman. It's a shame we lost him to the other side.
It's payback time.
Do you love him?
I don't think about it, Shakes. If I did, I'd say yes.
Where'd you get this evidence?
It fell into my lap.
In truth we were all surprised in Michael's action. But in his mind losing that game and handing a feeling of victory was more important to a girl in a wheelchair was more then the right thing to do.
You will be defenders of the faith. You will be soldiers of Christ.

[about why he won't play football]
Guards steer clear of me all right, they stay back and let me do my time. If I play in that game and put a hurting on one of them, that just might change my cushion.
Sweet Jesus! What have you boys done? What in the name of God have you boys done?
I think we just killed a man.
[Shakes is about to see Father Bobby]

[narrating]
Nokes warned us not to say anything to Father Bobby. If we did, the reprisals would be severe.
We haven't hit the hot dog vendor in couple of weeks.
I don't know Mike... The cart guy ain't like the others. I mean he gets pretty pissed, like crazy when you try to take him off.
We can eat hot dogs... or we can eat air... Choose.
Air is probably safer, Mike.

[after handing Detective Davenport surveillance photos and proof that Adam Styler's a crooked cop]
So, you got enough for conviction?
That ain't up to me. That's up to a jury.

[Hands Davenport a gun in a plastic bag]
Show the jury this.
What do you got there, Ness?
About 3 weeks ago, the body of a drug dealer named Indian Red Lopez was found in an alley in Jackson Heights. Three bullets in his head, nothing in his pockets.
I'm with you so far.
This is the gun that killed him, and these are the shells.
What's behind door number 3?
The prints on the gun belong to Adam Styler.
Hey, do me a favor, would you?
What's that?
If I ever make it onto your shit list, give me a call. Give me a chance to apologize.
Mug me or marry me, Shakes. I'm too tired for anything else.
So what do you want?
What I've always wanted. Is to watch you die!
Do you still sleep with the lights on?
Father Bobby would have made a good hit-man. It's a shame we lost him to the other side.
